advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> AN ADVERTISING</strong></font><br><blockquote>I couldn't resist putting this photo here. The girl looks very happy, the ad said "The new System III can be provided with walnut floor cabinet".</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert dédicated to Polymorphic BASIC language features and to a new version of the system named System 0.<br><br> The <b>System 0</b> was intended for the users who already have a S-100 Bus based system and wanted to transform it into a Poly 88 system. It consisted of the central processor card with ROM monitor, the video card and the cassette interface, all in kit form. Price: $525 </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUTER TERMINAL TO NETWORK STATION</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HiNet local network system allowed data to be transfered at a 256 Kbyte/sec. speed. It was able to run under CP/M or MS/DOS operating systems. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Efficient companies choose professional partners"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Evolutiv system : Casio's answer"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Apple hardware advertisement.<br> From Personal Computing, October 1983 issue<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode! If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then. Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics. Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (MAY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Computing pret-a-porter" <br><br> "Casio FX-702P : pocket Basic" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #4</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 RANGE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Choose from three computer systems:<br> The H-89 All-In-One Computer gives you everything in one compact, convenient unit.<br> The flexible H8 gives you the freedom to combine memory and interfacing for exactly the system you require.<br> And the powerful H11A gives you 16-bit power for your most complex programs.<br> The Heathkit line includes video terminals, matrix and letter quality printers, and accessories. You'll even find award-winning self-instruction packages to teach yourself programming in Basic or Assembly.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Pravetz Apple II compatible technology and price are compared with the IBM compatible Pravetz 8C.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Bojidar Stefanov</b> for the English translation</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>This reseller advert shows the initial price list from 1982 and the new prices of June 1983, about 40% less expensive.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE FRONT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Description of the complete Atmos system.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert puts forward network capabilities of Televideo systems.<br><br><font color="#666666"> ... If you want a personal computer that gives you professional performances, it's obvious that you have a lot of choices for today.<br> But there's only one with choices for tomorrow. Televideo ...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The sound, the color, the intelligence''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Part of a software advert<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The calculator was sold with a very helpful manual (Calculator Decision-Making Sourcebook) giving step- by-step examples for the best techniques used for solving mathematical, statistical and scientific problems, as well as programming tips.</blockquote>

computer.description:
Sheduled to be released in the U.S. in 1983 summertime, the PC-8201 was expected to compete directly with Tandy Model 100. Both machines were very similar, but the NEC could expand its internal RAM memory from 16 KB to 64 KB (only 32 KB for the Model 100).
The 8201's 32 KB ROM contained the operating system, Microsoft BASIC interpreter, a simple text-editing program and a telecommunication program. It could display the full 128 ASCII character set as well as Japanese Katakana characters and 61 user-definable characters.
Nec produced its own range of peripherals for the 8201, like a floppy disc controller (PC-8233) and various floppy drive units, including the most sold 3.5" unit (PC-8031). A video monitor adapter (PC-8240), an acoustic modem and a bar-code reader were also available.
Same hardware basis, made in fact by Kyocera, was also sold as the Tandy (TRS-80) Model 100 (USA), Olivetti M10 (Europe), and Kyocera Keytronic (Asia). _______________________
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke 67-key with 5 function keys and arrow keypad
computer.name: PC 8201A
computer.peripherals: External FD units, RAM expansion, external monitor adaptor, bar-code reader
computer.ports: RS 232 (DSUB 25 pin type), SIO1, SIO2 connectors, 8 pin duPont BERG modular jack - 3 megabytes/minute max transfer CMT socket - 8 pin DIN plug for cassette recorder, Standard centronics printer port, Bar code reader socket - 9 pin DSUB connector, SYSTEM SLOT - for ram cartridges (programs, software etc.)
computer.power: 4 x AA batteries, NiCad battery pack or AC adaptor (DC 6-8.5V, 600mW)
computer.ram: 16 KB up to 64 KB internally, and 128 KB via IC sockets underneath unit

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> BOTTOM SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><font color="blue"><b>(1)</b></font> Batteries housing<br> <font color="blue"><b>(2)</b></font> ROM / RAM extensions <br> <font color="blue"><b>(3)</b></font> Backup power switch<br><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Ray Payne</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><font color="blue"><b>(1)</b></font> External AC adaptor plug<br> <font color="blue"><b>(2)</b></font> RAM backup switch. RAM content can be saved when the computer is switched off.<br> <font color="blue"><b>(3)</b></font> Reset switch<br> <font color="blue"><b>(4)</b></font> Serial I/O ports 1 & 2 <br> <font color="blue"><b>(5)</b></font> Barre code reader plug<br> <font color="blue"><b>(6)</b></font> Parallel printer connector<br> <font color="blue"><b>(7)</b></font> RS-232 serial connector<br> <font color="blue"><b>(8)</b></font> Tape recorder DIN plug<br><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Ray Payne</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT & RIGHT SIDES</strong></font><br><blockquote><font color="blue"><b>(1)</b></font> Cartridges port<br> <font color="blue"><b>(2)</b></font> Batteries housing<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Ray Payne</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RED MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>The 8201 could be delivered with white, red or silver case.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SAME HARDWARE BASE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Like Philips which sells in Europe a part of its products range under Radiola or Schneider brands names, or Sharp pocket computers, also sold under Tandy name with minor design changes, these three computers (<$475$>Olivetti M10</a>, <$334$>NEC 8201</a>, <$233$>Tandy Mod. 100</a>)are, in fact the same model, manufactured by Kyocera company. If hardware part is basically the same, external design may differ. Olivetti propose a tilting display, Nec adds arrows keys, etc. Major purpose of this partnership is to reduce study and manufacturing costs. The same model, designed and manufactured by a single company should be 25% more expensive.</blockquote>
